messageBody:
I think the real reason it's off the beaten trail is because this code is
undertested since it usually ends up being a pain. I know that's been the
case with me. I tend to spend test effort where I am likely to find the
most bugs with the least work. The common practice seems to be to refactor
as much of the logic out of the GUI as possible, automate just enough of
the GUI test for sanity checking, then manually walk through it as part of
a functional test process. It's *not* entirely satisfactory, but does
(mostly) work.

On Thu, 27 Dec 2001, Lee Chalupa wrote:

> Thanks for your time Berin. I do appreciate it.
>
> My first assumption is that most programmers use jOptionPane frequently in the GUIs they write.
>
> My second assumption is that these programmers use Junit to test their GUIs including jOptionPane.
>
> Before I go deeper into the details of jOptionPane, I wonder if these are valid assumptions?
>
> If they are valid assumptions, I am curious. Why are my questions about this common approach unanswered or at least
> off the beaten trail? The response I have received leads me to believe that this path is less traveled which leads me to
> believe that I should be using another coding technique/approach that is more common.
>
> Can you help me understand this broader issue?
>
> Thanks again.
>
> lee
